title.narrative: YouthHub- Pushing for Reforms that Count

description.narrative:
‘Pushing for Reforms that Count for Nigerian Youths’ is an initiative of Youth Hub Africa, Onelife Initiative for Human Development, Foundation for Investigative Journalism and Social Justice, and Cedar Seed Foundation. The project seeks to expand the civic spaces in 4 Nigerian States and the FCT, leading to citizens increased tracking of government’s #EndSARS promises and a reduction of human rights violations.
The consortium proposes three solutions — ensure that the democratic demands of the movement are kept alive and promises of the government tracked to ensure its fulfilment; Mobilise actions that will track human rights violations particularly police brutalities in Nigeria and ensure that appropriate authorities are involved; and support Nigerian youths to be better organised and coordinated in demanding a better future.
The project will back the government's effort in asking aggrieved youths to sendin petitions and attend judicial panel hearings in 4 states — AkwaIbom, Oyo, Bauchi, Kwara and the Federal Capital Territory. Simplified public announcements on last-mile media outlets like radio and social media will be used with attention given to local languages. Violated unlettered youths and others will be supported to document their petitions and shown where to submit. The consortium will also facilitate legal support for petitioners through partnership with the local branches of the Nigeria Bar Association.

participating-org.narrative:
The actors are youth-focused and youth-led organisations with a cumulative of 26 years of experience working in the youth space in Nigeria.
YouthHubAfrica (Youth Foundation for Development, Education <(>&<)> Leadership) founded in 2011 is a platform for young people in Africa involved in social change to interact, learn and collaborate in new, creative and easy ways. YHA is a youth advocacy and policy-oriented organization based in Abuja, Nigeria, but programming into Africa and beyond. YouthHubAfrica had in recent timesbuilt communities of young advocates; emerging feminists; journalists community of practices; and rights defenders who use their existing platforms to advocate for sustainable development within their communities.
Onelife Initiative for Human Development, founded in 2014 is a non-profit organisation based in Oyo and Ekiti State that envisions a generation of young people enjoying improved quality of life and playing active roles in Nigeria’s development. Through its Governance and Policies desk, Onelife Initiative believes the youth population in Nigeria is the largest and leaving them illiterate about civic processes is dangerous for democracy. The organisation uses in-depth research, and knowledge networks to help young people make sense of government processes and systems by providing simplified information to them through easy-to-access channels.
The Foundation for Investigative Journalism is an independent not-for-profit organization that combats injustice, holds power to accountand speaks for the voiceless. Founded by ‘Fisayo Soyombo in June 2020, the organization seeks to uncover the truth by bypassing officialdom and neutralizing propaganda, and making it accessible to the public in a way that eases and influences their everyday decision making.
Cedar Seed Foundation runs with a mission of facilitating an enabling environment and providing services that support disabled people in Nigeria. It does this primarily through promotion of awareness on the rights of persons with disabilities and collaboration with key stakeholders in establishing linkages for access to social services
The collaboration is inspired by the diversity and varied niche that these 4 partners bring to the consortium in the youth-led and youth-focused space, and the community of Persons Living with Disability. YouthHubAfrica is able to bring its rich experience in policy and strategic advocacy for issues concerning young people to the table. Onelife Initiative bearssound experience in working with marginalized youths at the grassroot level with its deep use of local radio stations to expand itsreach. Foundation for Investigative Journalism bears the imprint of an investigative journalist of repute now working in cohort with a team of young journalistswho are using investigative approaches to exhume social injustices. Cedar Seed Foundation’s dense interaction and understanding of the special needs and rights of persons with disability is also in this blend.
YouthHub Africa has had its work supported by the UNFPA, UN Women, Malala Fund and other international non-profits. Onelife Initiative has had its work sponsored by Guaranty Trust Bank Plc, Amplify Change UK, Wallace Global Fund and a number of local organisations. FIJ has also experienced funding support from OSIWA.
